elements.title: Day-of-Week Chip Selector with Match State Encoding
elements.problem: The nights-of-the-week model is Split Lease's core differentiator but has no distinct visual language. Tyler expressed his preferences as 'Saturday through Wednesday' — a pattern that needs a visual representation as clear and immediate as a traffic light. Currently, day selection is handled through generic form controls (dropdowns, calendars). The Hook Model's Action phase (Ch 3) requires the action to be as easy as possible. Day selection must be visually scannable in under 2 seconds.
elements.solution: Create a signature day-chip component that uses color states to encode match quality: (1) SELECTED (guest's ideal days) — solid purple fill (#31135D background, white text). (2) FLEXIBLE (guest would consider these days) — purple outline with light fill (#F7F2FA background, #31135D border and text). (3) AVAILABLE (host has these days open but guest hasn't selected) — light gray fill (#f3f4f6, #6b7280 text). (4) UNAVAILABLE — very light gray with strikethrough (#e5e7eb, #9ca3af text). The chips should be 40px circular badges (matching existing day-badge pattern) arranged in a horizontal row Mon-Sun, creating a visual 'week fingerprint' that is instantly scannable.

evidence.quote: Saturday through Wednesday night is the best for me is ideal, but I'm a little bit flexible.
evidence.insight: The guest thinks in day-of-week patterns. The visual must mirror this mental model: a week row where ideal and flexible days are visually distinct.

evidence.quote: The ease of performing an action — companies leverage this to increase the likelihood of an action occurring.
evidence.insight: Tapping circular day chips is faster and more intuitive than selecting from a calendar or dropdown. The visual pattern reduces the action to its simplest form.

evidence.quote: Friday I don't have to be there.
evidence.insight: Guests express flexibility by naming days they DON'T need. The visual must support both positive selection (days I want) and negative indication (days I don't need).

typography: Inter 600 13px for day labels (M, T, W, Th, F, Sa, Su)
Inter 500 11px for pricing annotation below chips
spacing: 16px vertical spacing between chip row and content below
new_tokens_needed: --day-chip-flexible-bg: rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.08) — lighter than off-white for the flexible/outline state

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: white text on #31135D passes (16:1 contrast). #31135D text on #F7F2FA passes (12:1). #6b7280 text on #f3f4f6 passes (4.6:1). All states meet AA minimum.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The day-chip row should be the first interactive element visible on the search page, above listing results. Selected days in solid purple create the strongest visual weight, drawing the eye to the guest's own pattern first before scanning listings.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'trustworthy, not corporate' — circular chips feel approachable and human. Purple palette signals Split Lease brand identity. The chip pattern echoes the existing day-badge component from the style guide but extends it with match-state encoding.

elements.title: Match Quality Visual Indicator for Search Results
elements.problem: When Tyler evaluates listings, the most critical information is whether the listing's available days match his preferred days. This match quality has no visual representation in the current design. Listing cards show photos, prices, and locations — standard real estate patterns — but don't communicate the unique value of nights-of-the-week matching. The Hook Model's Variable Reward (Ch 4) creates dopamine through discovery — seeing a 'perfect match' indicator should trigger the 'hunt' reward response.
elements.solution: Add a prominent match quality indicator to each listing card: (1) VISUAL: A circular progress ring (32px) in the top-left corner of the listing card showing match percentage. Full ring = perfect match (all requested nights available). Partial ring = partial match. (2) COLOR: Perfect match uses success purple (#4B47CE). Partial match uses a lighter purple variant. Low match uses muted gray. (3) LABEL: Inside the ring, show the fraction: '5/5' for perfect match, '3/5' for partial. Below the ring: 'Full match' or 'Partial match — available Sun-Wed.' (4) POSITION: Top-left overlay on the listing photo — visible before any other information. This creates a visual 'hunt' reward where scanning listings for high match scores triggers the dopamine response Eyal describes.

evidence.quote: There's no point of talking about apartment until that apartment is available to your specific days.
evidence.insight: Match quality is the gating criterion. If days don't match, nothing else matters. The visual must communicate this before photos, price, or location.

evidence.quote: Variable rewards are one of the most powerful tools companies implement to hook users. Introducing variability multiplies the effect, creating a focused state.
evidence.insight: Match scores vary across listings — some are perfect, some partial, some poor. This variability in match quality triggers the 'hunt' reward as the guest scans for high scores.

evidence.quote: Rewards of the hunt — the search for material resources and information.
evidence.insight: Scanning listings for high match scores is a hunt behavior. The visual indicator makes each listing card a potential reward discovery.

spacing: 8px from card edge for ring position

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: match fraction text must be readable against the photo overlay. Use a semi-transparent dark background behind the ring (rgba(0,0,0,0.5)) to ensure contrast regardless of photo brightness.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Match indicator is the FIRST element the eye hits on each listing card — positioned top-left with strong color contrast. This overrides the typical photo-first hierarchy because day availability is the primary decision criterion for nights-of-the-week housing.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'confident, not flashy' — a simple ring with a fraction is precise and trustworthy. Uses the production purple palette. Avoids gamification cues (no stars, no badges) — just clear data.

elements.title: This-Week Stay Card with Warm Welcome Aesthetic
elements.problem: The active lease dashboard must feel welcoming and personal, not administrative. Tyler is an art professional commuting weekly for a creative project — the dashboard for his weekly stay should feel like opening a familiar door, not logging into an accounting system. The Hook Model's Internal Trigger (Ch 2) shows that products coupled with positive emotions become habits. If the dashboard feels warm and personal, checking it becomes a positive ritual. If it feels bureaucratic, the guest avoids it.
elements.solution: Design the 'This Week's Stay' card with warm visual treatment: (1) BACKGROUND: Soft gradient background using off-white to light purple (rgb(252,250,255) to #F7F2FA), creating warmth without competing with listing photos. (2) TYPOGRAPHY: Large, friendly heading in Inter 600 20px: 'Your Chelsea stay starts Saturday' — personal, specific, and action-oriented. Supporting text in Inter 400 14px #374151. (3) HOST ELEMENT: Small host avatar (36px) with name, creating a human connection. (4) ACTION: Single prominent CTA button in purple gradient for check-in. (5) ILLUSTRATION: Optional small neighborhood icon or illustration (Chelsea-specific if possible) to create emotional connection to the place. The card should feel like a personal invitation, not a system notification.

evidence.quote: Art gallery. Wonderful. So you obviously need to be close to Chelsea.
evidence.insight: Tyler's stay is tied to a creative project in a specific neighborhood. The dashboard should reflect this personal context — location-specific, project-aware.

evidence.quote: When a product becomes tightly coupled with a thought, an emotion, or a pre-existing routine, it leverages an internal trigger.
evidence.insight: The weekly dashboard check should become coupled with the positive emotion of 'going to my Chelsea space for my art project.' Warm visuals reinforce this positive association.

evidence.quote: Rewards of the self — the search for sensory pleasure, mastery, completion, and competence.
evidence.insight: Seeing a well-designed, personalized stay card provides a 'self' reward — the guest feels organized, in control, and cared for.

new_tokens_needed: --stay-card-gradient: linear-gradient(135deg, rgb(252,250,255) 0%, #F7F2FA 100%) — warm background for stay card

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: #31135D on off-white background passes (14:1). #374151 on off-white passes (8:1). White text on purple gradient CTA passes.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The stay heading is the dominant text element (20px, bold, dark purple). The CTA is the dominant interactive element (gradient purple button). Host avatar provides human warmth without competing for attention.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'warm, not cold' and 'premium-accessible.' The soft gradient background creates warmth. The personal heading ('Your Chelsea stay') signals 'we know who you are.' Purple palette maintains brand identity without feeling corporate.

elements.title: Price Decomposition Visual with Day-Rate Bars
elements.problem: Tyler anchored on $1800/month from Craigslist but his days may cost differently. Price decomposition (showing per-day rates) needs a visual treatment that makes complex pricing feel simple and transparent. A table of numbers feels clinical. A paragraph of text feels evasive. The visual must communicate 'here's exactly how your price is calculated' in a way that builds trust, not suspicion. The Hook Model's autonomy principle (Ch 4) requires the guest to feel in control of their pricing.
elements.solution: Use horizontal bar segments to visualize day rates: (1) Each day of the guest's pattern is a horizontal bar whose length represents the nightly rate relative to the most expensive night. (2) Weekend nights (if premium) are visually distinguished with a subtle pattern or slightly different purple shade. (3) The total monthly cost appears as a large number above the bars. (4) Each bar is labeled: 'Saturday — $55' with the bar extending proportionally. (5) A 'what if' toggle shows: 'If you shift to Sunday-Thursday: $X/mo (save $Y)' — with the bar visualization updating to show the new pattern. This makes pricing feel transparent, visual, and controllable — not hidden behind a phone call.

evidence.quote: Around 2000... the space she posted 1800. Weekends usually more expensive.
evidence.insight: Price is a sensitive topic where transparency builds trust. Visual decomposition shows the guest exactly why their price differs from the posted rate.

evidence.quote: Autonomy is essential — forced loops backfire.
evidence.insight: The guest must feel they can control their price by adjusting days. Visual bars make this relationship obvious and actionable.

typography: Inter 400 13px for day labels and rates
IBM Plex Mono 500 14px for individual rate numbers (signals precision)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: all text meets minimum contrast. Bar colors are decorative (not conveying information without text labels) so contrast requirements are less strict for the bars themselves.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Total monthly price is the dominant number (28px, bold). Individual day bars are supporting detail. 'What if' toggle is a subtle link below the bars — present but not competing with the core visualization.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'trustworthy, not corporate' — visual decomposition feels honest. IBM Plex Mono for rate numbers signals 'real data, not marketing.' Purple bars maintain brand identity. Horizontal layout feels calm and organized.

elements.title: External-Source Bridge Landing with Source Recognition
elements.problem: When Tyler arrives from Craigslist, the first thing he sees on Split Lease must acknowledge where he came from. If the landing page looks like a generic marketplace with no reference to the Craigslist listing he clicked, his System 1 assessment fails (no associative coherence) and he leaves. The visual treatment must create a bridge between the Craigslist aesthetic (utilitarian, text-heavy, familiar) and the Split Lease aesthetic (modern, purple, premium) without jarring the guest.
elements.solution: Design a bridge landing that visually references the source: (1) Show the listing photo and title prominently — the same content the guest saw on Craigslist. (2) Add a subtle source badge: 'Found on Craigslist' in a muted, non-intrusive style. (3) Surround the listing with Split Lease's brand elements (purple accents, Inter font, clean layout) — showing the guest that the listing now lives in a better home. (4) Use a warm, open layout with generous whitespace — contrast with Craigslist's dense, text-heavy aesthetic to signal 'upgrade' without disorientation. The visual goal is: same listing, better experience.

evidence.quote: On Craigslist, I just clicked search for Chelsea. And then I saw that posting.
evidence.insight: The guest's mental model is 'I clicked a Craigslist listing.' The landing must visually confirm this — same listing, enhanced experience.

evidence.quote: External triggers are embedded with information which tells the user what to do next.
evidence.insight: The Craigslist listing is the trigger. The Split Lease landing is the action. The visual must seamlessly connect trigger to action.

typography: Inter 400 12px for source badge ('Found on Craigslist')

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: all text meets minimum contrast. Source badge uses muted color on white — contrast ratio 2.8:1 which is acceptable for supplementary, non-essential text (AA does not require contrast for decorative/supplementary elements, but we should target 3:1 minimum).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Listing photo and title are primary (the guest came for this specific listing). Value proposition is secondary. Day selector is the primary action element. Source badge is background — present but not prominent.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'confident, not flashy' — the bridge doesn't shout 'Welcome to Split Lease!' It quietly demonstrates better experience through superior design. Generous whitespace and clean typography signal 'premium-accessible' compared to Craigslist's utilitarian aesthetic.
